subs.text: April 30

@SOSuburbia They can be built almost completely out of lumber in most places now due to building code changes over the last decade‚Ä¶ but 7+ stories requires masonry, reinforced concrete, steel, or custom timber engineering design and approvals.

Adding just one story more could kill profits.

subs.text: @Djsmokybacon Sadly, it‚Äôs unlikely to get better for a long while - it‚Äôs a world-wide problem. Two items of note from early February: - refining capacity is down, and - refiners are afraid of losing money on jet fuel by increasing crude processing rates. [link]
subs.rawText:
@Djsmokybacon Sadly, it‚Äôs unlikely to get better for a long while - it‚Äôs a world-wide problem.

Two items of note from early February: 
 - refining capacity is down, and 
 - refiners are afraid of losing money on jet fuel by increasing crude processing rates.

https://t.co/r0jDaaxK32

subs.text:
@Djsmokybacon In addition to current high natural gas prices (apparently needed to help process low-sulfur diesel), post-pandemic demand, and regional issues:

‚Äúthe global oil refining complex is under strain, with capacity falling for the first time in 30 years last year‚Äù

‚Ä¶ and ‚Ä¶

2/3

subs.text:
@jmcevoy_2 That quote doesn‚Äôt seem to support a claim of potential ‚Äúkidnap or murder‚Äù. 

At one point ‚Äúgrabbing him‚Äù is mentioned, but freeing him from extrajudicial extradition is hardly kidnapping.

The ‚Äúshooting‚Äù is in reference disabling aircraft tires, not people.

What am I missing?

subs.text: April 29

@Kurt_von_Bosse @TrentTelenko I recently interviewed an active USAF F-15 pilot (w/ about 12 years experience) about this.

When I asked how long it would take, for example, for her to learn to fly a F-16, she:

- laughed
- said it would likely take _years_

‚Ä¶

1/
subs.rawText:
@Kurt_von_Bosse @TrentTelenko I recently interviewed an active USAF F-15 pilot (w/ about 12 years experience) about this.

When I asked how long it would take, for example, for her to learn to fly a F-16, she:

- laughed
- said it would likely take _years_

‚Ä¶

1/

subs.text:
@Kurt_von_Bosse @TrentTelenko Being designed by two different contractors, the flight controls and displays are _completely_ different.

I pressed her and said, okay, but let‚Äôs say we‚Äôre at war, most of the F-16 pilots are dead‚Ä¶surely you can learn it faster if necessary, right?

Not that much faster‚Ä¶

2/
subs.rawText:
@Kurt_von_Bosse @TrentTelenko Being designed by two different contractors, the flight controls and displays are _completely_ different.

I pressed her and said, okay, but let‚Äôs say we‚Äôre at war, most of the F-16 pilots are dead‚Ä¶surely you can learn it faster if necessary, right?

Not that much faster‚Ä¶

2/

subs.text:
@Kurt_von_Bosse @TrentTelenko She explained, for example, that there are finger controls on the control sticks designed to replicate all of the flight / radio / navigation / etc. controls so the pilot doesn‚Äôt have to move their hands during combat flight:

3/4
subs.rawText:
@Kurt_von_Bosse @TrentTelenko She explained, for example, that there are finger controls on the control sticks designed to replicate all of the flight / radio / navigation / etc. controls so the pilot doesn‚Äôt have to move their hands during combat flight:

3/4

subs.text:
@Kurt_von_Bosse @TrentTelenko - these are _vastly_ different between the F-15 and F-16, and it can take years to build up the muscle memory to be able to operate them quickly, accurately, and automatically* ‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ while flying at very high speeds.

(* i.e. as ‚Äòautomatic‚Äô as you or I wiggling a thumb)

4/4
subs.rawText:
@Kurt_von_Bosse @TrentTelenko - these are _vastly_ different between the F-15 and F-16, and it can take years to build up the muscle memory to be able to operate them quickly, accurately, and automatically* ‚Ä¶

@DougCarlisle @TrentTelenko This is where mesh networks shine!

In reality, though, if you can get a clear signal when the container is loaded/unloaded by a crane, couldn‚Äôt tracking automatically just switch to following the ship? Power-save when stationary (i.e. in a yard) or in the dark?

subs.text:
@Behrooz60 @Aintropy @PhillipsPOBrien Sonic triangulation could be a simple and cheap possible method (i.e. cell phone microphones hidden in barns at known coordinates)

Alternatively: ISR drones, satellite ISR, RF triangulation, GPS transmitter on a fuze in an otherwise ‚Äòdumb‚Äô shell, luck‚Ä¶ or just local partisans.
subs.rawText:
@Behrooz60 @Aintropy @PhillipsPOBrien Sonic triangulation could be a simple and cheap possible method (i.e. cell phone microphones hidden in barns at known coordinates)

subs.text:
@glogeex @Aviation_Intel Satellites are too far away to _reliably_ communicate with legacy ballistic missile submarines at (or below) periscope depth.

The closer the transmitter, the easier it is to communicate through jamming or interference (e.g. interference caused by post-nuclear blast ionization).
subs.rawText:
@glogeex @Aviation_Intel Satellites are too far away to _reliably_ communicate with legacy ballistic missile submarines at (or below) periscope depth.

The closer the transmitter, the easier it is to communicate through jamming or interference (e.g. interference caused by post-nuclear blast ionization).

@DaveD1973 @MarkHertling That word seems to be reserved for mostly longer-range missiles?

Honestly, the whole ‚Äòhypersonic‚Äô thing seems like a lot of hype. Objects that fast can easily be audibly triangulated; stand-off radar picket lines can communicate with distant defense systems at nearly lightspeed.

subs.text:
@igorsushko Part of the point of the US releasing that intelligence was also to inform as many people as possible.

Advance notice of likely tactics allowed countermeasures to be put into place (e.g. disconnecting electrical transmission SCADA systems from networks, to prevent cyber attacks)

subs.text:

subs.text:
@Javier_F @BrianWhedon @Euan_MacDonald It sounds like the implication is that different sized ships are sometimes commanded by different ranks.

US Navy example:
 - Enlisted NCO commands motor launch
 - LT commanded WWII PT boat
 - CDR commands fast-attack submarine
 - CAPT commands cruiser

(generally)

subs.text: April 1

@TheRobinCommon1 @BeauTFC Uncertainty can increase the psychological pressure on an enemy as well.

Was it sabotage?

Was it NATO frogmen?

Was it divine retribution?

Was it rouge Russian pilots?

Did we deserve it somehow?

If these types of questions distract even one Russian soldier, that‚Äôs a win.
